I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan  and  (ii)  proposed  administration  of  a  loan  to  be  provided  by  the  OPEC  Fund  for 
International Development (OFID), both to the Kingdom of Cambodia for the Medium-Voltage 
Sub-Transmission Expansion Sector Project.1 
2.  The proposed project will expand the supply of reliable and cost-effective grid electricity 
in Kampong Thom, Kampong Cham, Siem Reap, Kandal, and Banteay Meanchey provinces in 
Cambodia.  It  will  (i)  expand  the  electricity  transmission  infrastructure  by  constructing 
2,110 kilometers  (km)  of  22-kilovolt  (kV)  sub-transmission  lines,2  (ii)  support  Electricité  du 
Cambodge  (EDC)  in  implementing  the  subprojects,  and  (iii)  improve  the  operational 
effectiveness and efficiency of EDC.3  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
1.  Socioeconomic Context 
3.  Cambodia’s power sector was severely damaged during long periods of conflict and civil 
war. Private, independent power producers4 using their own generation from imported diesel 
and heavy fuel oil were engaged in 1994 to provide electricity to main load centers such as 
Phnom Penh, Siem Reap, Sihanoukville, and other provincial towns through isolated systems. 
Since 2005, a primary focus of power development has been to build high-voltage (230 kV and 
115 kV) and medium-voltage (22 kV) sub-transmission lines to import electricity from neighbor 
countries  and  provide  affordable  services,  build  demand,  and  facilitate  grid  extension  by 
connecting the isolated systems. By 2012, four high-voltage lines were in operation, three at 
115 kV (414.95 km) and one at 230 kV (91 km). Development of three distinct grid systems is 
progressing in the southern, eastern, and northeastern economic zones. 
4.  At about 26%, the rate of household electrification in Cambodia is among the lowest in 
Southeast Asia—80% of Cambodia's population lives outside provincial and district towns, and 
only 11% of households in these areas are connected to grid electricity supply, mainly through 
isolated  systems  owned  and  operated  by  private  rural  electricity  enterprises  (REEs)  that 
generate their own power from imported diesel and heavy fuel oil. More than 11 million people 
use rechargeable car batteries for electricity supply, and kerosene and candles for lighting. 
5.  Electricity from rechargeable car batteries and REEs is expensive. In areas supplied by 
REEs, electricity tariffs are highly volatile due to fluctuating fuel prices and range from $0.65 per 
kilowatt-hour  (kWh) to $0.90/kWh.  For  electricity  from  rechargeable  car  batteries,  the  cost 
averages $1.00/kWh. 
6.  Besides being expensive, electricity services from REE-operated systems are generally 
unreliable and of poor quality. Coupled with high electricity costs, this severely constrains quality 
of life. Domestic firms and foreign investors name the high costs and supply shortages of 
electricity as a main constraint to doing business in Cambodia. This is critical, especially as the 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The term “sub-transmission” is applied in Cambodia to describe these lines in contrast to the distribution networks 
owned and operated by rural electricity enterprises (REEs). Sub-transmission lines transport bulk power supplies 
from the high-voltage grid to REEs. However, these lines should not be confused with high-voltage transmission 
lines—in terms of their scale and impacts these sub-transmission lines are equivalent to distribution lines. 
3  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2010. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Cambodia for Preparing the Rural 
Electrification Project. Manila.  
4  These are the REEs mentioned in footnote 2.

2 
government aims to diversify from garments to other sources of growth, such as commercial 
rice farming, other agribusiness, tourism, and light manufacturing. 
2.  Institutional Arrangements 
7.  The key  organizations  in  Cambodia’s  power  sector  are the General Department of 
Energy under the Ministry of Industry, Mines and Energy; the Electricity Authority of Cambodia 
(EAC); EDC; REEs; and other private domestic and foreign investors. 
8.  The General Department of Energy guides and supervises the development of the 
power sector and is responsible for overall energy planning, policy, and strategy. EAC is the 
country’s regulatory agency, responsible for issuing rules, regulations, and procedures and 
governing the power market operators, both suppliers and users. EDC, the country’s national 
power utility, is responsible for electricity production, transmission, and distribution in licensed 
areas assigned to EDC by EAC. 
9.  To supplement the capability of EDC in developing power sector infrastructure, the 
government is encouraging the private sector to invest. The promotion of private participation in 
electrification  is  also  anchored  in  Cambodia’s  Electricity  Law  (2001).  REEs  represent  an 
important  private  sector-based  framework  for  developing,  operating,  and  maintaining  the 
country’s  distribution  network.5  In  addition,  private  domestic  and  foreign  investors  are 
encouraged to invest in (i) oil and gas exploitation, (ii) energy generation from indigenous 
resources such as hydropower, and (iii) developing the high-voltage transmission system. 
3.  Subsector Problems and Constraints 
10.  Technical sustainability. Cambodia’s high electricity tariffs are caused by its power 
infrastructure, which is still dominated by isolated, inefficient generation and distribution systems 
powered  by  diesel  and  heavy  fuel  oil. With  the  realization  of  large-scale  domestic  power 
generation, the electricity grid will continue to evolve. It is planned that by 2015, large-scale 
power generation, mainly from hydropower, will reach 1,116 megawatts, all of which is to meet 
domestic demand estimated to grow at an average 26% per annum up to 2015. An additional 
1,489 km of 230 kV and 115 kV transmission lines are expected to be operational by 2015. 
11.  The expansion of power generation and the high-voltage transmission network requires 
that medium-voltage sub-transmission and low-voltage (<0.4 kV) distribution lines be developed 
commensurately to transfer electricity to consumers. It is estimated that about 17,000 km of 
medium-voltage  sub-transmission  lines  need  to  be  built  to  connect  the  isolated  systems 
throughout  the  country.  These  developments  will  help  displace  expensive,  unreliable,  and 
environmentally and health-wise hazardous off-grid diesel generation by REEs and will partly 
contribute to reducing electricity costs. EAC is implementing a tariff policy that requires REEs to 
gradually reduce retail tariffs to at least $0.28/kWh within 2–3 years of being connected to 
EDC’s 22 kV sub-transmission backbone.6 
12.  Financial capacity. EDC does not receive budgetary support. It needs to mobilize 
external financing to build the country’s grid-electricity infrastructure. While independent power 
producers are investing in power generation and construction of high-voltage transmission lines, 
EDC is primarily responsible for investing in the extension of medium-voltage sub-transmission 
                                                
5  Most REEs operate under a consolidated generation and distribution license. Most of the roughly 300 licensees In 
2012 are consolidated licensees. 
6  Through the connection to EDC’s 22 kV sub-transmission backbone, REEs will receive lower-cost electricity at a 
regulated bulk-supply tariff of $0.13–$0.15 per kWh. The tariff is discounted depending on the distance of the REE 
from EDC’s network. The cost savings are gradually transferred to end-consumers in public consultation with the 
serviced community. Although affordability to pay for electricity consumption must be considered, the tariff strategy 
aims to encourage REEs to further expand their distribution network into lower-density, higher-cost areas.

3 
lines. The cost of doing so beyond provincial towns, estimated at $21,000 per km, is high. 
Coupled with low population density and low consumption, the return on investment is marginal 
and will, without concessionary financing from development partners, imperil EDC’s long-term 
financial sustainability. 
13.  Affordability.  Affordability  represents  a  major  barrier  to  increasing  grid-electricity 
supply. On an average monthly income of $98, a household will need to pay $70–$120 to get 
connected to the grid (including connection fee, wiring from the meter, and house wiring). The 
government is trying to relieve the situation by piloting a scheme that provides lower-income 
households with interest-free loans to finance connection to the grid. The pilot is implemented 
by the Department of Rural Electrification Fund, a department established under EDC in August 
2012. The operational capacity of the department needs to be strengthened to scale up the 
interest-free loan scheme. 
14.  Human resource development. To allow EDC to efficiently and effectively keep pace 
with  the  expansion  requirements,  human  resource  capacity  in  the  key  business  areas  of 
strategic, operational, financial, information technology, and human resource management need 
to be strengthened, and pertinent strategies, policies, processes, and procedures need to be 
further updated, developed, and implemented. 
4.  Strategy and Road Map 
15.  In  its  National  Strategic  Development  Plan  (NSDP),  2009–2013,  the  government 
recognizes the importance of developing the energy sector to ensure socioeconomic growth and 
thereby reduce poverty to at least 19.5% by 2015. The government has developed the 2011 
Strategy  and  Plan  for  Development  of  Rural  Electrification  in  the  Kingdom  of  Cambodia 
(SPDRE) to achieve 52% household electrification by 2020 and 70% household electrification 
by  2030,  mainly  by  expanding  the  country’s  grid-electricity  infrastructure.  EDC  is  primarily 
responsible for investing in the expansion of the 22 kV sub-transmission backbone network to 
connect the grid substations of provincial towns to existing and new distribution networks owned 
and operated by REEs. REEs will continue to play an important role in providing electricity to 
consumers after connection to EDC’s sub-transmission grid. 
5.  Asian Development Bank Sector Experience 
16.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  greatly  contributed  to  the  expansion  of 
electricity access, sector reforms, and institutional capacity building by continuously supporting 
the power sector with investments and technical assistance.7 ADB’s country assistance program 
evaluation  for  Cambodia,  1998–2008  assessed  the  energy  sector  assistance  strategy  and 
program as relevant, effective, likely sustainable, and substantial in impact.8 
17.  The  country  assistance  program  evaluation  identified  efficiency  issues  related  to 
implementation delays. Delays can partly be attributed to EDC’s limited human resource and 
operating capacity for (i) finalizing detailed technical designs, (ii) handling procurement, and 
(iii) implementing  safeguard  measures  in  an  effective  and  timely  manner.  The  risk  of 
implementation delays under this project will be mitigated by (i) a high degree of readiness for 
subproject  implementation  with  detailed  technical  designs,  land  clearance  and  other 
government approvals, as well as advanced procurement in place before the proposed loan is 
                                                
7  ADB. 2003. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the 
Kingdom of Cambodia for the Greater Mekong Subregion Transmission Project. Manila; ADB. 2007. Report and 
Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Power Transmission Lines Co., Ltd 
for the Power Transmission Project in Cambodia. Manila; and ADB. 2006. Report and Recommendation of the 
President  to  the  Board  of Directors:  Proposed  Loan  to  the  Kingdom  of  Cambodia  for  the  Second  Power 
Transmission and Distribution Project. Manila. 
8  ADB. 2009. Country Assistance Program Evaluation: Cambodia. Manila.

4 
effective; (ii) engagement of consulting services to help EDC implement already-appraised 
subprojects and prepare additional ones; and (iii) building the capacity of EDC management and 
staff to prepare and implement safeguard compliance documents and measures. 
6.  Rationale for the Sector Loan Modality 
18.  A sector loan provides consistent and coordinated support to EDC with a critical amount 
of financing for physical and nonphysical investments in line with the objectives of the NSDP 
and SPDRE. Those objectives are fully consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy and 
its energy assessment strategy and road map for 2011–2013.9 Three of five subprojects to be 
financed as part of the sector loan have been appraised and approved with regard to their 
technical, financial, economic viability, and environmental and social sustainability. Two more 
subprojects, already determined, will be appraised and approved during the implementation of 
the project. The sector loan approach internalizes the appraisal and approval of these additional 
subprojects in accordance with technical, financial, economic, environmental, and social criteria 
mutually agreed upon between ADB and EDC.10 With the existence of a road map, subsector 
strategy, and institutional development framework strongly owned by the government and EDC, 
the key requirements for using the sector loan modality are met. 
7.  Development Partner Coordination 
19.  Development  partner  coordination  has  in  the  past  provided  the  government  with 
opportunities to synergize interventions from ADB, the World Bank, and bilateral partners, and 
to capitalize on best practices. Physical investment requirements of an estimated $1.0 billion are 
required  to  achieve  the  government’s  electrification  objectives,  exceeding  the  financing 
available from any one development partner. By providing financial support for improving both 
physical  infrastructure  and  institutional  development,  ADB  will  continue  to  add  value  to 
Cambodia’s energy sector. Moreover, through effective development coordination, ADB could 
leverage additional financing for this project from OFID. 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
20.  The project will contribute to increasing access to grid electricity in Cambodia. The 
outcome  of  the  project  is  expanded  supply  of  reliable  and  cost-effective  grid  electricity  in 
Kampong Thom, Kampong Cham, Siem Reap, Kandal and Banteay Meanchey provinces. 
 
C.  Outputs 
1.  Component 1: Expanding Medium-Voltage Sub-Transmission Network 
21.  Component 1 of the project will support EDC in the expansion of 22 kV sub-transmission 
lines. These sub-transmission lines will be connected from grid substations in provincial towns to 
existing and new distribution and service lines owned and operated by REEs. The project will 
finance  the  construction  of  2,110  km  of  sub-transmission  lines  divided  into  five  provincial 
subprojects: (i) 625 km in Kampong Thom, (ii) 184 km in Kampong Cham, (iii) 866 km in Siem 
Reap, (iv) 263 km in Kandal, and (v) 173 km in Banteay Meanchey province. Subproject 1 in 
Kampong Thom, subproject 2 in Kampong Cham, and subproject 3 in Siem Reap province have 
been fully appraised and approved. 
                                                
9  ADB. 2011. Country Partnership Strategy: Cambodia, 2011–2013. Manila. 
10 Subproject selection and approval criteria are in Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 2).

5 
2.  Component 2: Supporting EDC in Implementing Subprojects 
22.  Component 2 will support EDC in implementing the subprojects with a focus on finalizing 
detailed engineering design, procurement and contract management, construction supervision, 
testing  and  commissioning,  implementation  and  monitoring  of  social  and  environmental 
safeguards, project performance monitoring and evaluation. Project implementation consultants 
will complement existing staff of EDC, thus ensuring a high degree of implementation efficiency 
of subprojects financed under the project. On-the-job training to EDC staff in procurement and in 
the preparation and implementation of safeguard documents and gender-balanced compliance 
measures will be provided. 
3.  Component 3: Improving the Operational Effectiveness and Efficiency of 
EDC 
23.  Component 3 will support EDC in developing and implementing strategies, policies, 
processes, and procedures to effectively and efficiently manage its growing operations. Courses 
will be provided to EDC management and staff to strengthen the institutional capacity in various 
key operational areas including (i) strategic corporate planning and management, (ii) financial 
management and investment planning, and (iii) gender-balanced human resource management. 
This component will support the operational integration of the recently established Department 
of Rural Electrification Fund and will also include the rollout of EDC’s financial accounting and 
enterprise public utility organization management information system to its provincial branches. 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
24.  The project is estimated to cost $66.29 million (Table 1).

25.  The  government  has  requested  a  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to 
SDR29,071,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the project. The loan will 
have a 32-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions 
set forth in the loan and project agreement.11 Interest and other charges during construction will 
be capitalized in the loan. The government will act as the borrower and relend to EDC under the 
                                                
11 Loan Agreement and Project Agreement (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

6 
same terms and conditions, with an interest of 2.15% per annum during the grace period and 
thereafter. 
26.  ADB’s loan proceeds will finance goods and works for the construction of the 22 kV sub-
transmission lines, contingencies, financing charges during implementation, services related to 
supporting  EDC  in  implementing  the  subprojects,  and  strengthening  EDC’s  operational 
effectiveness and efficiency.12 
27.  The government further requested OFID to provide $10 million to finance jointly with 
ADB goods and works for the construction of the 22 kV sub-transmission lines.13 ADB will 
partially administer the OFID loan. The loan will have a 20-year term, including a grace period of 
5 years, and an interest rate of 2.5% per annum. The government will act as the borrower and 
relend to EDC under the same terms and conditions, with an interest rate of 2.65% per annum. 
28.  The government will finance taxes and duties ($8.89 million) through a tax exemption for 
EDC.  EDC  will  finance  costs  for  safeguard  mitigation  measures,  financing  charges  during 
implementation  with  regard  to  the  OFID  loan,  and  EDC  staff  resources  for  managing  the 
implementation of the project. The financing plan is summarized in Table 2.

7 
Procurement of goods and works, financed from ADB and OFID loan proceeds, 
will be in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended 
from time to time). Procurement of consulting services financed from the ADB 
loan will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). 
Advance contracting  Advance contracting will occur for goods, works, and consulting services in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines and ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants. 
Retroactive financing  Withdrawals may be made for reimbursement of eligible category 1 (works and 
equipment supply) expenditures incurred under the project before the effective 
date, but not earlier than the date on which OFID’s governing board has 
approved the OFID loan, and in any event not earlier than 12 months before the 
date of the ADB loan agreement, subject to a maximum amount equivalent to 
20% of the amount allocated for category 1. Withdrawals from the ADB loan 
account may be made for reimbursement of eligible expenditures incurred under 
the project for all categories except for category 1 before the effective date, but 
not earlier than 12 months before the date of the ADB loan agreement, subject 
to a maximum amount equivalent to 20% of the aggregate amount allocated for 
the categories.a 
Disbursement   The ADB and OFID loan proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB's 
Loan Disbursement Handbook (2012, as amended from time to time) and 
detailed arrangements agreed upon between the government and ADB. The 
direct payment procedure will be used.

management information system, ICB = international competitive bidding, NCB = national competitive bidding, OFID = 
OPEC  Fund  for  International  Development,  QCBS  =  quality-  and  cost-based  selection,  SSS  =  single-sourced 
selection. 
a  On 2 October 2012, ADB approved advance contracting and retroactive financing for goods, works, and services. 
OFID will confirm approval for advance contracting and retroactive financing on 12 December 2012. 
Sources: Asian Development Bank and Electricité du Cambodge. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
30.  The 22 kV sub-transmission line routes are generally designed along major roads.15 
Three-phase lines have been favored, as the lines will form the backbone of the grid-electricity 
network and can be subsequently overlaid with appropriate two-wire, single-phase spur lines for 
villages away from the major roads. The required transformer capacity, medium-voltage feeder 
route and rating have been sized on peak household demand assuming a standard load of 
0.375 kilovolt-ampere per household and considering that, within 5 years, at least 80% of 
households will be connected to the grid. The grid substations in Kampong Cham, Kampong 
Thom, and Siem Reap are currently supplied with imports from Viet Nam and Thailand. The 
power purchase is sufficient to service additional connections. The supply capacity from grid 
substations in provincial towns and the voltage performance were reviewed in a power system 
analysis. The project includes the installation of automatic voltage regulators to maintain voltage 
performance of long medium-voltage feeders. The design for subprojects 1, 2, and 3 is found to 
be technically viable. 
B.  Economic and Financial 
31.  Subprojects  appraised  for  the  project  are  economically  and  financially  viable.  The 
economic internal rate of return is 17.4%. The financial internal rate of return is 3.8%. The 
economic and financial internal rates of return exceed the economic opportunity cost of capital 
of 12% and weighted average cost of capital of 1.6%, respectively. The economic and financial 
                                                
15 Villages in Cambodia are largely linear in nature and aligned along major roads. Most villages are located within 
500 meters of the road.

8 
net present values are positive. Sensitivity analysis indicates that subprojects’ economic and 
financial internal rates of return are viable under stressed conditions. The subprojects generate 
a net financial and economic surplus.16  
32.  A review of EDC’s financial performance and projections concluded that EDC’s capital 
structure to meet its debt service requirements and its capacity to finance investments from 
internal resources are adequate. 
C.  Governance 
33.  EDC  has  implemented  several  high-voltage  and  medium-voltage  transmission  line 
projects funded by ADB, other development partners, and financing institutions. EDC staff have 
extensive  experience  and  sufficient  skills  to  implement  projects.  A  project  financial 
management, procurement, and implementation capacity assessment of EDC concluded that 
the executing agency has adequate financial accounting, auditing and reporting, procurement 
and implementation arrangements in place for implementing the project. However, EDC will be 
required to implement multiple transmission line projects up to 2020 that could constrain its 
human resource capacity. Therefore, consulting services to support and complement staff in the 
implementation of the project will be engaged. 
34.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and EDC. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM. 
D.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
35.  A household survey conducted in the project areas suggests that the primary use of 
commercial electricity supplies is to partially replace the use of kerosene for lighting and of car 
batteries for other electrical appliances. With the development of the 22 kV sub-transmission 
line network, the average electricity cost for consumers will be gradually reduced by at least 
60%, allowing households to increase consumption. Non-household consumers such as rice 
mills, craft work, and small service businesses are present in the project areas and economic 
activities are likely to increase with more cost-effective and reliable electricity supply. 
36.  The Department of Rural Electrification Fund is already implementing a pilot scheme of 
providing lower-income households with interest-free loans to finance the connection to the 
electricity grid. Component 2 of the project supports EDC with the operational integration of the 
Department of Rural Electrification Fund, which will involve the development of strategies, 
policies, processes, and procedures for scaling up the provision of interest-free loans to at least 
10,000 per year. The government and EDC have given their assurances to continue efforts to 
increase connectivity of households and lower electricity costs to consumers so as to maximize 
the socioeconomic benefits of the project. Support mechanisms are to be provided to all eligible 
households  irrespective  of  ethnicity,  gender  of  household  head,  or  other  conditions  of 
vulnerability. 
37.  Women occupy key roles in EDC in management, procurement, administration, finance 
and accounting, and corporate and business planning. The project supports the implementation 
of a human resource policy encouraging gender balance at all levels as well as capacity 
development of female staff in the various departments. In addition, the project ensures that 
100% of affected households headed by women are consulted on resettlement plans; joint 
certification of male and female household members is required on compensation receipts; and 
                                                
16 Economic Analysis: Project 1 and Financial Analysis: Project 1 (accessible from the list of linked documents in 
Appendix 2).

9 
an awareness campaign to prevent HIV/AIDS, other sexually transmitted infections, and human 
trafficking is conducted. 17 
 
E.  Safeguards 
38.  An environmental assessment and review framework and resettlement framework has 
been prepared for the project in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and 
Cambodia’s  regulations  and  guidelines.18  Both  frameworks  guide  EDC  and  the  project 
implementation consultants in preparing and implementing safeguard measures. 
39.  Environment. The safeguard category for the project is B for environment. An initial 
environmental examination report with an environmental management plan and implementation 
budget has been prepared in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and will be 
disclosed on ADB's website.19 No component of any of the three appraised subprojects is 
located in an environmentally sensitive or protected area, and adherence to good international 
construction practices will mitigate any potential impacts during construction. The main impact 
during  preconstruction  will  be  the  clearing  of  unexploded  ordnance  in  the  project's  sub-
transmission corridor, and before civil works begin, a certified unexploded ordnance clearance 
certificate needs to be obtained. 
40.  Resettlement and indigenous people. The safeguard category for the project is B for 
involuntary resettlement and C for indigenous peoples. A resettlement plan with an estimated 
compensation budget has been prepared in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
and will be disclosed on ADB's website.20 No physical relocation will be required and, in this 
case, the term “resettlement” relates to limited acquisition of livelihood trees and crops. Potential 
impacts will be limited to the installation of concrete poles using about 0.2 square meters of land 
and the stringing of conductors requiring the trimming of some tree branches. Some trees may 
need to be removed in a few villages and market areas. The estimated impact of tree removal is 
1 tree per 2 km, including productive trees such as mango, palm, coconut, and tamarind. 
41.  The environmental assessment and review framework, resettlement framework, initial 
environmental  examination,  and  resettlement  plan  were  disclosed  on  ADB’s  website  on 
1 October 2012. 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
42.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and detailed in the 
relevant plan.21  
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Implementation delays caused by lengthy  Readiness for implementation ensured with detailed technical 
approval processes for loan effectiveness,  designs, government approvals, and advanced procurement and 
land clearance and compensation,  implementation processes; regular review missions conducted for the 
procurement, and construction  timely handling of potential problems 
Implementation delays caused by delayed  Selection of subprojects for financing under the project take into 
construction of associated power  consideration the time frame and commissioning status of directly 
generation and transmission projects not  associated projects; sequencing of implementing subprojects to allow 
financed by the Asian Development Bank  for a degree of responsiveness to changes in the commissioning of 
associated projects

documents in Appendix 2). 
19 Initial Environmental Examination: Subprojects 1, 2, and 3 (accessible from the linked documents in Appendix 2). 
20 Resettlement Plan: Subprojects 1, 2, and 3 (accessible from the linked documents in Appendix 2). 
21 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
Household connection delays caused by  Government assurance to continue implementing adequate tariff 
limited financing capacity of rural  policy and financing mechanisms to allow rural electricity enterprises 
electricity enterprises to invest in  to further expand distribution network; government and Electricité du 
distribution network expansion and of  Cambodge (EDC) assurances to allocate enough resources (staff 
households to finance connection could  and budget) to the Department of Rural Electrification Fund for 
undermine financial sustainability and the  scaling up interest-free loan scheme; support provided to strengthen 
socioeconomic impact of the project.  capacity of the Department of Rural Electrification Fund for scaling up

continue implementing subsidy mechanisms to reduce electricity 
tariffs 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
43.  The government and EDC have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
44.  The government and EDC have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project as 
are set forth in the loan and project agreements. 
 
45.  The  following  condition  for  loan  effectiveness  is  included:  The  subsidiary  loan 
agreement, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, has been duly executed and delivered 
on behalf of the government and EDC, and all conditions precedent to its effectiveness, other 
than a condition requiring the effectiveness of the ADB loan agreement, have been fulfilled. 
 
46.  The following condition for withdrawal for works and equipment supply is included: No 
withdrawal shall be made for works and equipment supply  until the OFID loan agreement has 
been duly executed and delivered, and all conditions precedent to its effectiveness, other than a 
condition requiring effectiveness of the ADB loan agreement, have been fulfilled. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
47.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR29,071,000 to the Kingdom of 
Cambodia for the Medium-Voltage Sub-Transmission Expansion Sector Project, 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% 
per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, for a term of 
32  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
and project agreements presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the administration by ADB of a loan not exceeding the equivalent of $10,000,000 
to  the  Kingdom  of  Cambodia  for  the  Medium-Voltage  Sub-Transmission 
Expansion Sector Project, to be provided by the OPEC Fund for International 
Development. 
   
  Haruhiko Kuroda 
22 November 2012  President

metadata.Keywords: cambodia; rrp; energy transmission; power transmission; electricity; rural electricity; kampong thom; kampong cham; siem reap; kandal; banteay meanchey; eléctricité du cambodge; grid electricity; edc; 42361; project tems and conditions
metadata.Subject: This document provides the report and recommendation of the President (RRP) on (i) a proposed loan and (ii) proposed administration of a loan to be provided by the OPEC Fund for International Development (OFID), both to the Kingdom of Cambodia for the Medium-Voltage Sub-transmission Expansion Sector Project. The RRP describes terms and conditions proposed for the project for the approval of the Board of Directors of ADB.
metadata.Title: RRP: Cambodia: Medium-Voltage Sub-transmission Expansion Sector Project

  EAC  –  Electricity Authority of Cambodia 
  EDC  –  Electricité du Cambodge 
  km  –  kilometer 
  kV  –  kilovolt 
  kWh  –  kilowatt-hour

  OFID  –  OPEC Fund for International Development 
  PAM  –  project administration manual 
  REE  –  rural electricity enterprise 
  SPDRE  –  Strategy and Plan for Development of Rural Electrification in 
the Kingdom of Cambodia 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.
